Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, eyes fixed on a group of teenagers laughing and pushing each other dangerously close to the no-diving signs. As a lifeguard, I knew my duty was clear: enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, even if it meant being the “bad guy.” My supervisor expected vigilance, and the parents trusted me to protect their kids. But as I watched the clock inch closer to ten, my thoughts drifted to the church service starting soon. Sunday worship was more than a routine for me—it was a time to reconnect with my faith and community, something I’d been missing lately because of these weekend shifts. The pastor always said our presence mattered, that we were part of something bigger. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me: the responsibility to keep these kids safe, and the longing to be present in worship, to not let my faith slip away. My heart pounded as I glanced between the rowdy teens and the time ticking by, torn between the pool deck and the pews, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
